A new series of polytopic ligands based on 1,10-phenanthroline and polyoxadiamines has been synthesized through SNAr amination between 2-chloro-1,10-phenanthroline and diamines of various structures. The obtained podands were investigated as polytopic ligands for potassium and zinc ions in the industrially important reaction of cyclic carbonates synthesis from CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions (p(CO2) = 1 atm., T = 60–80 °C). The advantage of 1,11-diamino-3,6,9-trioxaundecane functionalized by 1,10-phenanthroline units compared to the diamine itself is demonstrated. It is revealed that heteroarylated 1,11-diamino-3,6,9-trioxaundecane can be used as a catalyst in the presence of KI (2 mol.%) with a low loading of the ligand (0.2 mol.%) instead of the usually employed 5–10 mol.% for unfunctionalized podands. Under these reaction conditions mono-substituted cyclic carbonates of various structures have been synthesized in excellent preparative yields ranging from 87 to 99%. Coordination of two Zn(II) ions to both 1,10-phenanthroline moieties has been shown to provide additional enhancement of catalytic activity. The catalysts demonstrate excellent stability and can be reused at least in 6 cycles. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Polytopic ligands 1,10-phenanthroline 2-amino-1,10-phenanthroline Podands CO2 fixation Cyclic carbonates Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The conversion of CO2 into valuable compounds and materials attracts the attention of researchers, since carbon dioxide is a cheap and accessible C1-synthon [1–4]. On the other hand, the problem of reducing CO2 content to prevent climate change encourages the search for new ways of converting carbon dioxide into valuable products [5]. At present, many reactions using CO2 have been proposed for both fine organic synthesis and large-scale processes [6–12]. The synthesis of cyclic carbonates through the carbon dioxide reaction with epoxides is a crucial industrial process. Cyclic carbonates are applied as degradable polar aprotic solvents in organic synthesis, as electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries and as potential monomers for polycarbonates synthesis [13–16]. Therefore, the search for optimal conditions for their synthesis is quite actual task. Conducting these reactions under mild conditions, namely, at atmospheric pressure of carbon dioxide and temperatures below 100 °C is of great interest and requires an active search for efficient catalytic systems [1,4,7,17,18]. The accepted mechanism of the cyclic carbonates formation from carbon dioxide and epoxides involves the activation of epoxide by Lewis acid (LA) which is followed by nucleophilic attack of a “naked” nucleophile (usually halide anion) and CO2 insertion in the O–LA bond. Finally, intramolecular nucleophilic substitution of the halide leads to formation of the product. Many homogeneous [19–27] and heterogeneous [28–36] catalytic systems based on various metal complex Lewis acids have been proposed for this reaction. Complexes of Al(III) [1] and the first-row transition metals, such as Zn(II) [37,38], Cu(II) [39], Co(II/III) [40–43], Ni(II) [44] and Fe(II/III) [45,46] with various ligands are widely studied as Lewis acid in this reaction. However, the search for approaches to create advanced catalytic systems is still ongoing. To date, some of the most cost-effective and readily available catalysts for this transformation are systems based on complexes of potassium or calcium iodides with polyoxa-ligands. These ligands include a wide variety of glycols, polyglycols, polyamines, podands, crown ethers and polymers based on them (Scheme 1 ) [29,47–60]. These systems enable reactions for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates from epoxides at atmospheric pressure of CO2 (1 atm.) without the need for solvents at temperatures ranging from 25–100 °C [29,47–60]. The success of using such catalysts lies in the efficient chelation of the alkali or alkaline earth metal cation, which not only increases the solubility of the introduced salts, but also provides the generation of an active “naked” nucleophile that readily opens the epoxide. Additionally, alkali or alkaline-earth metal coordinated by polyoxa ligands can activate the epoxide as a Lewis acid [29,47–60]. Activation of the epoxide is also possible through the formation of hydrogen bonding between free OH/NH groups in glycols or polyoxaamines and oxygen atom of the epoxide [47,60]. While these systems are well established, there is no mention in the literature of the study of heterocycle-functionalized derivatives of polyoxaamines or polyglycols in this reaction. However, it is known that noncyclic crown-type polyethers modified with heterocycles such as pyridine or quinoline lead to the formation of more stable complexes with alkali or alkaline earth metals than the polyethers themselves [61–64]. Additionally, heterocycle fragments are capable of selective chelation of transition metal ions forming Lewis acid center [27,42,65]. Such a novel “bifunctional” catalytic system, which can bind alkali metal ions by polyoxa-linker and transition metal ions by heterocyclic moiety, simultaneously, could enhance the catalytic efficiency of the reaction [41,50]. In this regard, 1,10-phenanthroline is particularly interesting as a heterocycle for modification due to its high chelating ability to metal ions and its electron-acceptor heterosubstituent property [66–68], which significantly decreases the nucleophilicity of the amino-substituent in thepositions 2 and 4 of the heterocycle [69]. This property can be useful for tuning a nucleophilicity of amine-groups (NH2), because there are known to open epoxides as well [70,71]. Furthermore, there are several examples of the use of zinc complexes based on 1,10-phenanthroline ligands in the transformation of epoxides and CO2 into cyclic carbonates and polymers [72,73]. To note, transition metal imine complexes are promising catalysts for the studied reaction and can be considered as more structurally rigid analogs of salen complexes, which are well-known catalysts for converting epoxides into cyclic carbonates through reaction with CO2 [74,75]. In the course of the present study, we have synthesized a new series of polytopic ligands based on the 2-amino-1,10-phenanthroline motif linked by polyoxadiamine tether, which are potentially capable of coordinating both alkali metal ions and transition metal ions. Such bifunctional catalytic systems based on coordination of two metals are considered to be promising for the reaction of CO2 and epoxides [29]. The idea was to increase the catalytic activity of podand-based system by introducing a heterocyclic moiety (Scheme 1). The investigated systems allow to decrease the loading of the catalysts from the usually used 5–10 mol.% to 0.2 mol.% in cyclic carbonates synthesis under mild conditions. The ligand provides an active nucleophile (iodide anion) through effective coordination of K+. Additional catalytic activity enhancement is achieved by Zn(II), as a more active Lewis acid than the potassium cation, introduced to the 1,10-phenanthroline fragments. Thus, the synthesized polytopic ligand can be used as a component of a more active catalytic system both by itself and in the form of Zn(II) complex. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis of the catalysts The novel polytopic ligands L1–L6 based on the 2-amino-1,10-phenanthroline motif were synthesized through SNAr amination from 2-chloro-1,10-phenanthroline (Scheme 2 ). Arylation of amine 1 and diamines 2–6 was carried out in the presence of K2CO3 in a DMF solution at 140 °C. The products L1–L6 were purified using gradient column chromatography and isolated in good preparative yields. To introduce the Lewis acidic centers Zn(II) complexes a series of the complexes were synthesized from these ligands (Scheme 3 ). At this step, we focused on ligands containing three oxygen atoms in the chain to provide better chelation for K+ cation. The ligand L5 was utilized to prepare complexes with different stoichiometric ratios of Ligand : Zn(II) 1:1 and 1:2 resulting in Zn(L5) and Zn2(L5) (Scheme 3). Additionally, we prepared the Zn(L1)2 complex to serve as a reference system for further catalytic experiments. All complexes were synthesized by the reaction of the corresponding ligand L1, L4 or L5 and anhydrous ZnBr2 in dry dichloromethane at room temperature under an argon atmosphere for 24–48 hours. All newly synthesized compounds were characterized using NMR spectroscopy, IR spectroscopy and mass spectrometry (see ESI). 2.2 Catalytic activity in cyclic carbonates synthesis The reaction between styrene oxide (7a) and carbon dioxide was selected as a model reaction for initial catalytic tests. At first we investigated the L/KI catalytic systems in order to identify the ability of the podands L1–L6 to release iodide anions from KI. The synthesis of cyclic carbonate 8a was conducted in the presence of L1–L6 (2 mol.%) and KI (2 mol.%) at 50 °C without a solvent (Scheme 4 ). It was found that ligands L1–L3 were inactive in this process and only yielded the target cyclic carbonate in 2–6% yields (Scheme 4). Therefore, it can be concluded that the 2-amino-1,10-phenanthroline fragment itself does not effectively chelate potassium ion. Ligands L4–L6 were more reactive and L5, the best among them, produced cyclic carbonate 8a in a 20% yield and high selectivity under these reaction conditions (Scheme 4). However, further optimization of the reaction protocol is necessary, the presence of both the 2-amino-1,10-phenanthroline fragment and polyoxa-linker in one molecule showed a positive effect compared to L1. The reaction result also depends on the number of oxygen atoms in the linker structure. This effect was previously reported in the literature when glycols or podands are used in this reaction [51,60], but there are no examples of functionalized podands by 1,10-phenanthroline yet. Since the catalytic system L5/KI was found to be the best among those tested, it was used for further optimization of the reaction conditions. Surprisingly, the loadings of the ligand L5 could be decreased to 0.2 mol.% with only a twofold loss in yield (Table 1 , Entries 1,2). Increasing the temperature to 80 °C resulted in a product with an excellent isolated yield of 99% (Table 1, Entry 3). Changing the ratio of L5 : KI from 1:10 to 1:1 decreased the yield of 8a (Table 1, Entry 4). Control experiments confirmed that the reaction does not occur in the absence of L5 (Table 1, Entry 5), nor does it proceed with the system 1,11-diamino-3,6,9-trioxaundecane 5/KI (0.2/2 mol.%) (Table 1, Entry 6). Introducing the heterocyclic moiety to diamine 5 resulted in a more effective catalyst that is 30 times more active than the system 5/KI (Table 1, Entries 3,6). However, increasing the catalyst loadings of 5 to 10 mol.% and KI to 20 mol.% resulted in only 30% yield of 8a, with the selectivity of the reaction being lost and by-products of 7a homopolymerization of the epoxide being observed (Table 1, Entry 7). In comparison to L5, the mixed ligand system 5/1,10-phenanthroline (Phen) was also tested, yielding the product in only a 7% yield (Table 1, Entry 8). This result undoubtedly indicates the positive effect of phenanthroline and amine 5 fragments binding in one molecule. The activity of different salts was also investigated (Table 1, Entries 9–11). In the case of potassium chloride (KCl) low conversion was observed, while sodium iodide (NaI) and potassium bromide (KBr) afforded 8a in comparable yields of 62% and 42% respectively (Table 1, Entries 9–11). This effect of alkali metal salts in this reaction is known in the literature, and the positive effect of potassium iodide (KI) is explained by the ability of the iodide anion to perform as a better leaving group [47]. Zinc(II) complexes, which were expected to be more active systems, were tested in the model reaction at 50 °C in the combination with potassium iodide (KI). However, the complex Zn(L5) was inactive and only produced traces of 8a in 24 hours (Table 1, Entry 12). The same negative result was obtained when the temperature was increased to 80 °C (Table 1, Entry 13). We believe that the hollow formed from a linker as a result of zinc coordination to 1,10-phenanthroline sites does not allow for potassium cation coordination, as zinc is blocked by two ligands for epoxide activation. Indeed, if the complex is formed in situ, the activity of such a system was 13 times higher compared to Zn(L5) (Table 1, Entry 14). Taking this into the account we did not study the complex Zn(L4) which has shorter tether with only two oxygen atoms causing its lower ability to K+ binding. The reaction did not occur when a mixture of salts ZnBr2/KI without ligands was used (Table 1, Entry 15). Another type of zinc coordination to a polytopic system, implemented in the dinuclear complex Zn2(L5), demonstrated excellent results. The catalytic system Zn2(L5)/KI (0.2/2 mol.%) yielded the target compound in a 90% preparative yield after 24 hours at 60 °C (Table 1, Entry 16). However, the complex Zn2(L5) was active, but it did not work without potassium iodide co-catalyst, which provides nucleophile for epoxide ring opening (Table 1, Entry 17). Increasing the temperature to 80 °C and reducing the reaction time to 6 hours enabled the formation of 8a in a good 57% yield (Table 1, Entry 18). The reference system Zn(L1)2 /5/KI (0.2/0.2/2 mol.%) was also tested at 80 °C, yielding only 15% of the target product after 24 hours (Table 1, Entry 19). NMR monitoring of the model reaction was conducted with two systems: polytopic ligand L5 and Zn2(L5) with the addition of potassium iodide (KI) as a co-catalyst in all cases, at milder conditions of 60 °C (Fig. 1 A). It was found that introducing the Lewis acidic Zn(II) to both 1,10-phenanthroline sites in L5 gives a more effective catalyst that is 10 times more active than the L5/KI system (Fig. 1A). The reuse of L5/KI and Zn2(L5)/KI catalytic systems was investigated (Fig. 1B,C). Evaporation of the product from the reaction vessel under reduced pressure (ca. 1 Torr, 160°С) followed by adding the next portion of epoxide 7a to the residue allowed for the restarting of the reaction. Both the catalysts were shown to be stable and active at least in 6 cycles, the product 8a was formed in 86–95% yield after 24 h in each cycle (Fig. 1B,C). Notably, that the selectivity of the reaction also remained high. The conversion to the product 8a reached >95%, when the reaction time was increased to 30–48 h. Since the catalytic activity of systems L5/KI at 80 °C and Zn2(L5)/KI at 60 °C was similar the Zn-free system L5/KI (0.2/2 mol.%) was chosen for the study of the scope and limitations of the reaction under optimized reaction conditions. Cyclic carbonates of various structures were obtained (Scheme 5 ). The most commonly used substrates with various steric hindrances were tested. Compounds 8a–e were synthesized in excellent preparative yields ranging from 91–99%. In order to obtain 8f and 8g an increase in temperature to 100 °C is required. This temperature adjustment is necessary due to the improved solubility of L5 in epoxides 7f and 7g at 100 °C compared to 80 °C. However, cyclohexene epoxide (7h) is less reactive in this reaction, resulting in only a 25% yield of 8h even with higher catalyst loadings. Despite this, the selectivity of the reaction remains high. 2.3 Structural and mechanistic studies Two investigated systems L5/KI and Zn2(L5)/KI show increased catalytic activity at 80 °C and 60 °C, respectively, in the synthesis of 8a compared to the system of diamine and potassium iodide 5/KI (0.2/2 mol.%). The increased catalytic activity of the dinuclear Zn(II) complex Zn2(L5) can be explained by an active Lewis acid, that causes better epoxide activation [1], allowing a decrease in temperature from 80 °C to 60 °C in the synthesis of 8a. However, the 30-times increase in catalytic activity of L5/KI (0.2/2 mol.%) compared to diamine and potassium iodide 5/KI (0.2/2 mol.%) at 80 °C was unexpected. To clarify this phenomenon, 1H NMR spectra of the ligand L5 and complex [K(L5)]I were recorded in acetone-d 6 with the addition of CD3OD (50 µL). The complex [K(L5)]I was prepared using a ratio of starting reagents L5 : KI 1:10 by mixing in methanol and was analyzed after solvent evaporation (see ESI). Both compounds L5 and [K(L5)]I have poor solubility in acetone-d6 , that is why methanol is required. Notably, the choice of solvent is crucial for elucidating such systems by NMR. If DMSO-d6 is used no difference is observed between systems L5 and [K(L5)]I by 1H NMR, due to the competing role of DMSO in associating potassium iodide. The 1H NMR spectra of L5 and [K(L5)]I are depicted in Fig. 2 . Both spectra are plotted on the same δ scale and have clearly divided aromatic and aliphatic regions. The former is represented by the typical heteroaromatic system of 1,10-phenanthroline, which consists of seven signals which were assigned basing on coupling constants, multiplicity and additive schemes (Fig. 2, Table 2 ). The aliphatic part of the spectra is represented by four multiplets assigned to a, b, c and d protons basing on literature data (Fig. 2, Table 2) [76]. The formation of the potassium-complex [K(L5)]I results in changes in the chemical shifts of both aromatic and aliphatic signals in the 1H NMR spectrum compared to L5 but in a different manner (Table 2). As shown in Fig. 2, protons c and d in [K(L5)]I have a downfield shift compared to L5, which undoubtedly proves the formation of the potassium complex mainly through the oxygen-sites of the polytopic system. The signals of NH protons were not observed under these conditions because of exchange with methanol-d4. Surprisingly, the aromatic region of the [K(L5)]I spectrum changed synchronously with an upfield shift compared to L5 (Fig. 2, Table 2). The most significant difference in chemical shifts, more than 0.1 ppm, was observed for protons at the positions 4, 5, 6, 7 and 8 in the 1,10-phenanthroline core (Table 2). The values of coupling constants remain the same only for protons at the positions 3 and 4 of 1,10-phenanthroline, while they change for protons at the positions 5–9 (Table 2). 1H NMR spectra of the 1,10-phenanthroline-based podand L5 and its potassium complex [K(L5)]I were also recorded at various temperatures (Fig. S3). Interestingly, lowering the temperature to 0 °C resulted in broadening signals in the L5 NMR 1H spectrum, likely due to a decrease in the rotation speed of molecular fragments, while the signals of [K(L5)]I remained unchanged (Fig. S3). Recording a 1H NMR spectrum with a modified ratio of L5 : KI 1:0.5 led to the formation of complexes with different structures and average chemical shifts between signals for L5 itself and [K(L5)]I due to rapid dynamics. This result highlights the significance of the L5 : KI ratio of 1:10 for robust complexation, consistent with catalytic studies. The formation of complexes of composition [K(L5)] + and [K(L5)(ZnBr2)2]+ was confirmed by mass-spectrometry (Figs. S5 and S6). The activation of epoxide by the complex [K(L5)]I was also observed through 1H NMR (Fig. S4). As shown in Fig. S4, the chemical shifts of the epoxide experienced a synchronous downfield shift in the presence of the catalyst compared to styrene oxide itself. The activation of the epoxide by K+ complexes with glycols in this reaction was previously reported in the literature [29,47–60]. The role of hydrogen bonds between the OH groups of glycols and NH groups of polyamines and oxygen in the epoxide has also been previously discussed [77]. 1,10-Phenanthroline and its salts can also serve as a platform for hydrogen bonds formation [78]. However, we did not observe such interactions by IR spectroscopy between NH hydrogen atoms in L5 and an oxygen atom in the epoxide. As an alternative explanation, we proposed the presence of a π-stacking between the 1,10-phenanthroline moieties. These interactions between heteroaromatic units facilitate K+ effective coordination via pseudo-crown type complex formation, promoting nucleophilic catalysis. π-Stacking interactions between aromatic rings are known to result in the shielding of proton signals in 1H NMR due to the anisotropy of the ring current effect [79,80]. Since our attempts to grow a single crystals of L5 or [K(L5)]I for X-ray diffraction analysis were unsuccessful, DFT calculations were conducted to support this hypothesis. The optimized geometry of the complex [K(L5)] + was obtained using DFT in the ORCA v.6.0.0 program package [81] on the def2-svpd basis on light atoms and def2-tzvpd on the potassium atom using the PBE functional and dispersion correction for a more accurate description of non-covalent interactions in the system (Fig. 3 a). The average distance between two 1,10-phenanthroline rings was found to be 3.54 Å, consistent with known systems with π–π stacking showing 3–4 Å [79,80]. Considering the up-field shifting of the aromatic signals in the 1H NMR spectrum of [K(L5)]I, we propose that π–π stacking between two 1,10-phenanthroline units takes place which leads to effective potassium binding and provides 30-fold increased catalytic activity compared to podand 5. The coordination of styrene oxide to potassium atom in [K(L5)]+ complex was also supported by DFT calculations (Fig. 3b). The mechanism based on NMR experiments and DFT calculations is shown at Scheme 6 . In the case of Zn2(L5)/KI catalytic system, the mechanism is proposed to be the same, but differs only by the coordination of the epoxide to the Zn(II) atom. To summarize, based on NMR investigations and DFT calculations, we conclude the formation of the potassium complex [K(L5)]I, which is stabilized by π–π stacking between two 1,10-phenanthroline units forming a pseudo-crown structure. As a result of this coordination, the “naked” iodide anion facilitates opening of the epoxide ring through its nucleophilic attack. 3 Conclusions New polytopic ligands with a 2-amino-1,10-phenanthroline motif and oxadiamine fragments L1–L6 were synthesized using SNAr amination reaction from 2-chloro-1,10-phenanhroline. Based on ligands L1, L4 and L5 Zn(II) complexes Zn(L1)2, Zn(L4), Zn(L5) and Zn2(L5) were synthesized and characterized. The positive effect of the introduction of 1,10-phenanthroline fragments to the trioxadiamine on its catalytic properties in the reaction of epoxides and CO2 was demonstrated. The catalytic systems L5/KI and Zn2(L5)/KI were found to be efficient in the reaction of cyclic carbonates synthesis under mild reaction conditions (p(CO2) = 1 atm., T = 80 °C and 60 °C, respectively) using KI as a co-catalyst and low catalyst loadings (0.2 mol%). These catalysts were reused in 6 cycles without loss of activity and selectivity. The catalytic system L5/KI (0.2/2 mol%) yielded mono-substituted cyclic carbonates of various structures in excellent yields ranging from 87 to 99%. In the case of L5/KI system phenanthroline moieties provide more effective K+ cation complexation due to π-stacking interactions which facilitates iodide anions release for nucleophilic catalysis. In the case of Zn2(L5)/KI system 1,10-phenanthroline forms Zn(II) Lewis acidic center for epoxide activation which allows the reaction to be carried out at a lower temperature. The role of 1,10-phenathroline moieties in the catalysts was supported by experimental (NMR, HRMS) and theoretical (DFT) studies. 4 Experimental section 4.1 Materials and methods Unless otherwise noted, all chemicals and starting materials were obtained commercially from Alfa-Aesar, Acros and Aldrich–Sigma Co and used without further purification. Preparative column chromatography was carried out using Silica gel 60 (40–63 µm) from Merck Co. CH2Cl2 was distilled over CaH2; DMF was distilled over CaH2 under reduced pressure; MeOH was used freshly distilled. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded with the Bruker Avance-400 spectrometer in CDCl3, CD3CN, acetone-d6 or DMSO-d6, using the residual signals of CHCl3, CHD2CN, CD3C(O)CD2H or CD3S(O)CD2H as internal standards. MALDI TOF mass-spectra were obtained with the Bruker Daltonics Autoflex II mass spectrometer in positive ion mode with dithranol matrix and poly(ethyleneglycols) as internal standards. ESI mass-spectra were obtained on the TripleTOF 5600+ mass-spectrometer (AB Sciex) (Voltage 5.5 kV for positive ions mode, 4.5 kV for negative ions mode; ion source gas 15 arb, curtain gas 20 arb; eluent MeCN + 0.1% HCOOH). High-resolution mass spectra [K(L5)]+ and [K(L5)(ZnBr2)2]+ were recorded on a SolariX XR FT/ICR mass spectrometer equipped with a 15 T superconducting magnet, a ParaCell analyzer cell and an ESI Apollo II and MALDI SmartBeam-II ion source. External calibration of the mass spectrometer was performed using a low-concentration sodium trifluoroacetate solution (0.1 mg/mL in acetonitrile/water, 1:1). FTIR spectra were registered on Nicolet iS 5 with iD3 ATR accessory (ZnSe). Elemental analyses (EA) were performed with Fisons EA-1108 CHNS elemental analyzer instrument. Detailed information on synthesis and characterization of the ligands (L1–L6) and complexes ((Zn(L1)2, Zn(L4), Zn(L5) and Zn2(L5)) is given in the Supporting Information. 4.2 General procedure for the reaction of epoxides with CO2 A Schlenk tube (5 mL) equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a condenser was evacuated and backfilled with CO2, for three times. Then the Schlenk tube was charged with epoxide (5.5 mmol), ligand (L1–L5, 0.2–2 mol.%) and potassium iodide (2–10 mol.%) in a CO2 stream. The reaction mixture was stirred at 50–80 °C for 24 h under CO2 atmosphere (1 atm.). After cooled to room temperature, the probe of the reaction mixture (50 μL) was added to an NMR tube, diluted with CDCl3 (0.6 mL). The yield of cyclic carbonates was determined by 1H NMR analysis using methyl 3,5-dinitrobenzoate as an internal standard. If needed, the reaction mixture was purified by flash-chromatography on silica gel (CH2Cl2 as eluent) to afford cyclic carbonates. Characterization data and NMR spectra for the isolated products are given in the Supporting Information. 4.3 DFT studies The calculations were performed using ORCA 6.0.0 program package [81]. DFT calculations were performed at PBE [82] level of theory using def2-SVPD [83] basis set for light atoms and def2-TZVP [83] basis set for K atom. Calculations utilize the atom-pairwise dispersion correction based on EEQ partial charges [84] to better describe weak interactions. Cartesian coordinates of all optimized structures are given in the Supporting Information. CRediT authorship contribution statement Violetta A. coredata.dc:description: A new series of polytopic ligands based on 1,10-phenanthroline and polyoxadiamines has been synthesized through SNAr amination between 2-chloro-1,10-phenanthroline and diamines of various structures. The obtained podands were investigated as polytopic ligands for potassium and zinc ions in the industrially important reaction of cyclic carbonates synthesis from CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions (p(CO2) = 1 atm., T = 60–80 °C). The advantage of 1,11-diamino-3,6,9-trioxaundecane functionalized by 1,10-phenanthroline units compared to the diamine itself is demonstrated. It is revealed that heteroarylated 1,11-diamino-3,6,9-trioxaundecane can be used as a catalyst in the presence of KI (2 mol.%) with a low loading of the ligand (0.2 mol.%) instead of the usually employed 5–10 mol.% for unfunctionalized podands. Under these reaction conditions mono-substituted cyclic carbonates of various structures have been synthesized in excellent preparative yields ranging from 87 to 99%. Coordination of two Zn(II) ions to both 1,10-phenanthroline moieties has been shown to provide additional enhancement of catalytic activity. The catalysts demonstrate excellent stability and can be reused at least in 6 cycles.

coredata.dc:title: Bifunctional catalysts based on 2-amino-1,10-phenanthroline-containing podands for cyclic carbonates synthesis from CO2 and epoxides under mild conditions
